control inbound access to those ec2 instances now that's a pretty simple way
to get started on ec2 and launching your instances but we heard from customers that actually would like a few more

ACL so other security controls around the networking environment inside AWS so
in 2009 we then launched V PC and that gave you all of these features a little

avicii - classic so where we just launched an instance in the immediate house public and private IP addresses

of both worlds so inside an AWS account with a default V PC you now have a pre
created environment that gives every instance of public and private IP address the same as ec2 classic but it
also gives you a way to start being able to leverage those additional features that are available in V PC so if you
have an account that was created after April 2013 you may actually only have access to the V PC environment so here's
our first dive into some command line examples so this is using the AWS command line interface and we're calling

access to ec2 classic and V PC or just V PC in this example it's V PC only okay
so a typical conversation I have with customers talking about using V PC using
networking on AWS typically starts with a hybrid conversation so we have our corporate datacenter we want to get
started on AWS how do we do that so what we're going to be doing here is building up an architecture on the screen and
we're going to start with that corporate datacenter now the first thing we need to do inside AWS is create our V PC now
V PC is defined by a cider block a block of IP addresses and therefore you see the first command line example down at
the bottom of the screen here is a call to ec2 to create a V PC the only thing
we have to specify when we create that V PC is the cider block the block of IP addresses and that now gives us the
container to hold the rest of our resources once we've done that we need to create some subnets within that V PC
now a subnet is assigned to a particular availability zone so the two final commands you see on the screen here at
the bottom are request to create a subnet we're going to assign it a block of IP addresses within our cider block
for the VPC and we're then going to specify which availability zone we want this subnet to be created in so in my example
here we now have two subnets created within our V PC this is great we've got our our environment ready to go what do
we need to do next well perhaps we need to establish some connectivity back to our corporate environment so here we're
going to use an IPSec VPN now this has a few additional steps involved in creating this so you can see the first
step is to create the VPN gateway or the virtual private gateway we then attach that to our V PC so they're the first
two examples you see here now you can see the first request is to create the VPN gateway and we specify a type of
IPSec now that's the only type of VPN that we support but we do support two different variations of it both dynamic
and Static a little bit more about those later on once we've created that VPN
gateway the virtual private gateway on our V PC and attached it we now need to define the other end of that VPN
connection and we call this the customer gateway so the third line on the command line example there is to create the
customer gateway again we're specifying this is an IPSec gateway but we now call out what the customer IP address is so
this is the IP address on your end of that VPN connection because we're going to be using a dynamic VPN here so based
on BGP a routing protocol we're also going to specify the a s number for the remote end of this connection finally we
now need to link these two together so we have our two gateways on each end and the final call here is to link the two together and create our VPN connection
now when we do that we actually make a whole set of example configurations available for you to download you can do
all of this obviously via the web interface but you know this is expert mode this is why we're looking at the command line so you can make a call and
say give me the configuration for my Rooter so we have a whole bunch of standard devices that we provide the
configuration for it's important to remember that this is absolutely standard IPSec VPN so actually if you
have pretty much any solution that supports BGP encrypted by IPSec you
should be able to take our configuration parameters and get this VPN up and running
okay so we have our V PC creator we have our VPN linking our environments together let's get some compute
resources actually running inside our V PC now I'm sure you're familiar with this but we're going to call the run
instances API here we're going to specify our Amazon machine image that we want to launch from we're going to also
specify which subnets we want to launch into now that's a slight difference here between a ec2 classic environment and V
PC in classic you wouldn't have to specify the subnet but inside V PC we do and then finally because it's just as
easy to launch one instance as is a thousand we can just pass a parameter at the end that says we want to launch three of these instances so now our V PC
contains six ec2 instances three in each subnet connect it back to our corporate environment now up until this point
we've used IPSec VPN to establish this connectivity and the thing about an IPSec VPN is it's running over the
internet so it's subject to internet weather events or interruptions in service things that are outside all of
our control so if you perhaps have an application running inside V PC that needs a more consistent connection so
perhaps some higher bandwidth predictable latency then you might consider Direct Connect so Direct
Connect is made up of a few components but one of the big differentiator is about Direct Connect compared to a VPN
is it has this physical component it presents a physical port on a Rooter in
a Direct Connect location that you need to establish a connection to so though we're going to interact with it via the
API and request the ports request the interfaces that I'll talk through in a moment we do need to get a connection to
that port and that's where you can work with one of our Direct Connect partners to establish connectivity back to one of
our Direct Connect locations so the steps in the API calls here are first of all let's request a connection so create
connection specify the location in this case Equinix SC to a bandwidth of one
gigabit now we support port speeds of either one gig or 10 gig you can get
less than one gig via one of our partners if needed and then finally we're going to give this connection a name once we've created our
physical connection we now need to create what we call a virtual interface on this physical connection and a
virtual interface is a combination of a VLAN bgp session so we only support BGP for
routing over Direct Connect we don't support static routing or any other routing protocols so our second request here is to create
a private virtual interface we're going to specify the connection that we requested in the first step we're then
going to say that we actually want to specify the VLAN ID the BGP is number
the BGP authentication key these are all standard BGP parameters finally the IP
address for each end of this BGP session the one final piece of the puzzle we
need here is actually where do we want to attach this and in this case we attach both direct connect and VPNs to
the Virtual Private gateway on our V PC so now we have the two connections that are shown on the screen here from an
Amazon perspective we will always prefer to send traffic over a Direct Connect if it's available rather than the VPN so we
now have a good level of resilience for our solution now you would have thought
at this point that we have all of our connectivity sorted well we do but we don't have any routing in place yet so
whether we have the connectivity in place traffic can't flow between our corporate data center and our V PC when
you create a V PC we create something called the main routing table and inside that routing table is a single entry
it's called the local route and it tells all of the subnets how to reach each other but there are no other entries in
that routing table so what we need to do now is actually add an entry into that routing table which is what the CLI
example is at the bottom of the screen here I'm going to specify default route so 0.0.0.0
/ - that destination go via the Virtual Private gateway which then uses the
direct connect or the VPN to get to the corporate datacenter so this is a good

these are delivered into two different endpoints on the AWS end of the connection and the customer gateway is

another router inside the corporate data center established another VPN which gives you another two IPSec tunnels

thank you very much okay so we're going to go back to our connectivity solution that we were building with our V PC now
so far we've talked about connectivity back to the corporate data center we had our VPN and our Direct Connect in place
we'd put our entries in our routing table and sending all traffic back to our corporate data center so what if we
have an application that's running inside our V PC though that needs direct internet access that you don't want to send back via the corporate data center
or perhaps an application that's being consumed from the internet that we're hosting inside the V PC this is where
the internet gateway fits in so our command line examples again at the bottom of the screen our first request
is to create an Internet gateway now this is an object that we're going to attach to the V PC it doesn't represent
any single point of failure or or anything like that it's a highly available service that we provide to
allow access to and from your V PC to the Internet once we've created that internet gateway we need to attach it to
the V PC this is very similar to what we did with the virtual private gateway so now we have the ability to send and
receive traffic to them from the internet but in a very similar way to the virtual private gateway we now need to configure our routing so what we're
going to do first is delete the routing entry that we created in our main routing table that was sending traffic back to the corporate data center so
removing that default route that's the third example here next we're going to create a new route entry it's a default
route again 0.0.0.0 slash zero but this time we're going to specify that we should send that traffic via the
internet gateway so now we don't have access to and from the internet but what about the corporate datacenter we
removed that earlier so finally we're going to create a more specific route at the bottom here back to 192 168 0 dot 0
which represents our corporate data center so in this case we're going to specify the Gateway as the virtual
private gateway from earlier with the Direct Connect and the VPN now you
notice there that we created a effectively a static route entry for the corporate data center what if you have a
network environment there's quite dynamic where things change perhaps you have a global MPLS Network and you have
networks being added and removed fairly frequently this would be an admin overhead for you to maintain this
routing table so we have a feature that's called route propagation so in the examples shown here what we're going to do is remove
that static route that we actually created a moment ago and instead enable route propagation and what that says is
all of the routes that we receive from you over Direct Connect or over VPN we're going to automatically put those
into the routing table for you inside your V PC so now you haven't got to maintain that manually another
requirement I often hear from customers is I want to run all of my resources inside a V PC but I have some that I
just want to be available to the Internet and I don't want them to know to reach back into the corporate environment now obviously we could just
create another V PC and not have a connection back to the corporate environment but in this particular case what we're going to do is create
something called an isolated subnet so you can see the first request you should recognize that from the beginning of
this session where we created the subnets we're creating another subnet we're specifying a cider block of 10.30
and we're specifying which availability zone we want to create the subnet in we're now going to use a feature that I
haven't mentioned so far which is the ability to have multiple routing tables inside your V PC so we're going to
create a new route table that's the second request and we're now going to associate this new route table with our
subnet so at this point we have an empty routing table just has one entry in it that says local it can reach all of the
other subnets in the V PC but it doesn't know how to get out to the Internet and it doesn't know how to get to the corporate environment so finally we're
now going to create a route inside that particular route table that says to get to the internet go via the internet
gateway we haven't enabled route propagation and we haven't created a static route back to the corporate data
center so quite simply this subnet is isolated from that corporate environment traffic cannot route to and from it from
the corporate network one other feature that we often see
customers deploying is either an app instance so network address translation or a firewall inside their V PC that
they want to route all traffic through once again we're going to use the feature I mentioned a moment ago of multiple routing tables to make this
possible one thing I do want to cover first though is a security feature that
we have in the ec2 hypervisor environment which is called source destination checking what this is is a
feature that says all traffic going towards an instance inside your V PC must be destined for that instance or
originated from that instance if it isn't it never gets through to the ec2 instance itself now in the case of a NAT
instance or a firewall we obviously want to be able to pass traffic through this instance that is destined for somewhere else it's going to be inspected by the
firewall or address translated so the first thing we need to do for this instance is disable that source
destination checking so you can see the command here in ec2 is to modify the network interface attributes we specify
the elastic network interface for that ec2 instance and we disable the source destination checking once that's done we
now need to manipulate the routing tables inside the V PC to send all traffic from most of the other subnets
so in this case the the main routing table we're going to specify destination of 0 0 0 0 again the default route but
instead of specifying the internet gateway or the Virtual Private Gateway we're going to actually specify that
particular instance so the NAT or firewall instance so now all traffic that is trying to leave this V PC is
going to be routed to that NAT instance now the subnet that has the NAT instance in it obviously needs internet access so
we're now going to use the additional routing table we created that is attached to that subnet and in this one
we specify a default route of the internet gateway so they are using two different route tables to deliver
traffic first to the NAT instance then from there out to the Internet

a Solutions Architect at Amazon Web Services based here in Israel and today I'm going to talk a little bit about BBC peering so VPC peering is a networking
connection between two V pcs that enables you to route traffic between Z pcs using private IP addressing and what
this means is that in stress that instances in either V PC can communicate with each other as if they were on the
same network now it's important to note that V PC peering is a service and much
like other V PC services such as the Internet gateway it does not rely on a separate piece of physical hardware
there's no single point of failure nor does it pose a bandwidth bottleneck
so we see a number of common use cases for VP CPOE and one of the big ones is
what we call the shared services vbc so customers say to us you know I'm creating multiple VB sees I have many
applications and I want to create some sort of isolation between those applications but at the same time
they're also a set of services that a set of services that all of those applications need access to so that set
of service can be authentication monitoring logging so one of the use
cases that we see VPC peering provide is this kind of topology so in this case
for example I have VP CA which represents my shared services V PC a and with VB say and with VP CA all the other
the application specific VB sees can now peer in order to consume the common
services that VP CA has to offer so I will administer the core services in VB
CA and the individual application owners will be able to administer the systems that run in their VB sees another common
use case we see is called infrastructure zoning whereby I might have one vbc from
my development environment another for my test environment and another for my production environment so I'd work on my
code in my development environment and once it's ready I will commit it and deploy it to my test environment and
once all my tests are completed I will then deploy it to production and one of the really cool things about this is
that you can actually create identical environments so your development and
your tests and your production VP C's can literally get the same IP addresses and the same VPC configuration so that
when you promote your code from V BC B to C to D you could be sure that you're
testing your applications in a completely identical environment to which it's run in production you would
then use Bastion hosts deployed in a common V PC to access the different
development production and tests VP C's for the purpose of administration
sorry so how do I actually create vbc
peering it's actually quite simple there are a number of API is that we use and the first one that we'll implement is
create VPC peering connection to which I will pass the IDS of the two VP sees
that I'd like to peer you then have to accept the peering connection from the
other VPC so we require a handshake to happen before we can establish a VPC
peering connection and that handshake is the create followed by the accept so in
this case I created it and then I accepted it by referencing the VPC
peering connection ID which is in the format of PCX - something and so in my
second command I'm accepting that peering connection once the parent connection is established I then just
have to update my routes I update the routing tables on both sides to say that
any traffic going to the other VPC goes through my peering connection so peering is just another target or just another
route target similar to the virtual private gateway and the Internet gateway
now vbc peering can also be used across accounts and I often see this used by
AWS customers who are software as a service providers who want to peer with their customers bbc's / private IP
addressing and the difference between this case and the previous one is that in this case I need to specify the peer
owner ID which is the 12 digit AWS account ID and the purpose of that is to make sure I know which account I'm
peering with the peer owner then needs to accept that it accept the pairing
connection by issuing the accept peering connection command and so again both
accounts have to establish a handshake to the respective VP C's in order to appear with the respective EP C's so
there are few other things to think about when setting up your VPC peering in order to enable access to your VP C's
you need to configure security groups in their respective V pcs to use IP
versus of the instances in the peer VPC secondly we don't support transit
capabilities so for example if you have three V pcs that need to communicate with each other you need to set up
pairwise communication between those V pcs as we do not support the capability

peer with a third V PC as long as the two V pcs that share a parent connection do not have overlapping IP ranges now
